Note: Data on lending totals derived from the portfolio analyses differs from the data derived from the thematic coding system used Bank-wide. The primary source of this difference lies in the multiple themes that the Bank-wide coding systems applies to a given project, whereas the data in the table are derived exclusively from an assessment of the spatial orientation of investments. Numbers may not add to totals because of rounding. a. Method used for spatial distribution of commitments via Investment instruments: Review of Appraisal Document of all projects approved in a given fiscal year; investments related to spatially located project components (e.g., urban slum renewal, rural health clinics) are assigned to the relevant category; in cases where projects are national in scope (e.g., national primary school enrollment), the urban-rural population ratio is used to apportion investment according to national definitions; "no direct rural or urban" refers to investments which do not impact directly on rural or urban populations (e.g., national banking reform). b. Method used for spatial distribution of commitments via adjustment instruments: Review of policy matrix in the Program Document; first, based on the OPCS guidelines for assigning sector codes to adjustment operations, commitment amounts to spatially relevant policy items (e.g., land policy, maternal and child health insurance, prevention and treatment of HIV/AIDS) are assigned percentages reflecting the frequency with which the item occurs in the policy matrix; second, commitment amounts to these items are then divided between urban and rural areas according to urban and rural population based on national definitions. c. Supplementary commitments were $164 million in fiscal 2003.

doc.abstracts: The World Bank Annual Report for 2003, reviews the strategy and action pursued by the Bank, based on the Strategic Framework, and Strategic Directions (and Management Action Plan), focused on meeting the development challenges embodied in the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). To this end, the Bank sharpened its policies, programs, and instruments to support its central mission of reducing poverty, through improved performance monitoring, and management, and improved harmonization of operational policies, procedures, and practices among donors. The Bank also considered other issues, such as its role in the reconstruction of Iraq, the introduction of the grants component in the 13th Replenishment of the International Development Association (IDA), the Operation Evaluation Department's (OED) review of the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative, and, market access for exports from developing countries. Methods for combating terrorism, and money laundering were also considered during the period under review. The document presents thematic (and regional) perspectives based on two pillars - poverty reduction and economic management - and how to invest in people, towards an environmentally, and socially responsible growth, that supports private sector development, infrastructure development, financial management, and, promotes appropriate legal and judicial systems. The second Volume presents the financial statements for the period July 1, 2002 to June 30, 2003, reporting development activities (loans, guarantees, and other activities), including liquidity management, funding resources, and financial risk management.
